column2:
This message has been posted to the restricted agents only forum in your help desk. It is not visible to your end-users. Feel free to delete.

How does this thing work? Users email requests to support@schoology.zendesk.com or submit requests online at http://schoology.zendesk.com.

Requests appear in your email inbox and as tickets in your views. Leave replies for users via email or online - either way, all communication is recorded right here in your zendesk and both you and your users are notified of all ticket updates. Users can login and reply or simply reply via email.

More to explore:

  • Personalize your help desk with colors, logo and text

    If you want the help desk and the support e-mail address in your own domain, you can configure that too.

  • Review how your users access your help desk

    By default your help desk is almost completely open. Anybody can submit tickets and view your community forums.

  • Invite your colleagues by registering them as help desk agents or end-users

    Or ask them to register themselves by visiting the sign-up page or by sending an e-mail to support@schoology.zendesk.com.

  • Submit tickets to get a feel for the system

    Create an end-user with a different e-mail address than your own, and submit some tickets on behalf of that end-user.
    Assume that user and see how things look like from the end-user perspective.

  • Review and customize email notifications

    Notifications are sent per default to agents and ticket requesters upon ticket updates via triggers.
    You can also reconfigure your automations. Automations are business rules that work on an hourly basis.

Digging deeper

Create and modify ticket views. Review and reconfigure the default SLA service targets. Set ticket priorities, ticket form appearance and more by configuring ticket form fields. Organize your users in organizations and agents in groups. And there’s lots of reports to help you gauge the performance of your help desk service. Finally, there is a plethora of API options for the tech savvy.
column4: Welcome to your Help Desk!

column2:
Headings

If there is more than one area to describe in an article, the first heading you should utilize Heading 1. The order of headings and sub-headings should be as follows:

  • Heading 1
  • Heading 4
  • Heading 3
  • Heading 2

In most cases, you’ll only use one or two heading sizes (Heading 1 and Heading 4, for example).

If you are using Heading 1, add a line after the heading by:

  1. Clicking on the HTML editor.
  2. Entering <hr></hr> directly after every </h1>.

 

Spacing

  • When starting a new Header 1, make sure you’ve created an extra line of space (return key).
  • The space after a Header 1 area should be formatted Paragraph.
  • There should be one space after each period.

 

Hyperlinks

  • Link URL: All hyperlinks (blue) should be checked to make sure they navigate to a Zendesk Forum article or valid web address.
  • Link Title: The hyperlink title should be the name/title of the article or address to which it points. If the title requires role information, place the role in parentheses (Teachers). Please put an “s” at the end of the role name, except “System Admin.”

 

Bullets & Numbering

  • Bullets: Please format your sentences in such a way that bulleted items are continuations of sentences, or sentences themselves. Each bulleted item should end with a period, except for circumstances where the list is solely a list.
  • Numbering: Numbering should occur when listing steps to complete a process.

 

Notes

Notes that follow a description should be bold, and should not be indented.

Note: This is a note.

 

Enterprise

Enterprise features are marked by writing (Enterprise) after the title of the feature.

 

Quotation Marks, Underline, Italics

Please refrain from using quotation marks, underline, or italics. The first time a feature or area of Schoology is mentioned, use capitalization to highlight the feature (E.g. My Resources is…). When using the word in the same description area, you can use lowercase to refer the feature (E.g. You will find even more tools to organize your resources…).

 

Terminology

When possible, use words found in Schoology (e.g. Assignment rather than Homework). Please use these words and spell these words in the manner you find them in Schoology (e.g. Advisor rather than Adviser).

column2:
This article explains what to expect when using the Clever app to provision data from a Student Information System to Schoology. 

 

This article will address the following questions: 

  1. How does Clever work?
  2. What information is transferred from Clever to Schoology?
  3. What information is transferred from Schoology to Clever?
  4. How often is information sent to Schoology?
  5. What is required to implement the Clever App in Schoology?
  6. How long does it take to get the integration working? 
  7. What are the limitations to the Clever integration?

 

Overview

Schoology has developed a Student Information System (SIS) integration platform that enables Schoology to integrate with any SIS that provides a web services API. The integration provides a seamless method for keeping Schoology populated with users, courses, school, and enrollment data. Schoology has integrated with Clever (www.getclever.com) to enable provisioning from over 50+ student information systems. The integration replaces the need for districts to manually maintain data in Schoology via uploads. Clever provides automated provisioning of school information, users, grading periods/terms, courses, sections, and enrollments. 

 

1) How does the Clever work?

  • The district should visit https://getclever.com/schools/signup/schoology to sign up for Clever.
  • For complete instructions please view Clever's documentation here - click here

2) What information is transferred from Clever to Schoology?


Schoology will pull the following information from PowerSchool: 

  • School building information
  • Users (staff and student accounts)
  • Grading periods/terms
  • Courses, Sections, and Enrollments

 

Important Note: All of the information listed above will be managed in the districts Student Information System and changes and updates will be transferred seamlessly to Schoology via Clever. However it is important to note that any changes or updates made in Schoology will not be transferred back to your Student Information System.

 

3. What information is transferred from Schoology to Clever?

Clever does not currently support the transfer of data back from Schoology.

column2:
Enterprise Launch Pack Introduction

This launch pack provides System Administrators with instructions to successfully establish a working framework for implementation with Schoology.  Our recommended framework includes a review of roles, permissions, grading periods, courses, enrollment, and possible login configuration. As you can see from the Table of Contents, we've broken up the broken up the process into four general steps: 

  • Step 1: Setting Up the Framework
  • Step 2: User Management 
  • Step 3: Course Creation
  • Step 4: Course Enrollment

After reviewing this launch pack, Client Success Specialists will be available for further review, questions, as well as product training sessions as needed during implementation.  Any customized training sessions, such as on-site training or recurring sessions, should be discussed with your sales representative.  We can work with you to help facilitate any communication.

 

Client Responsibilities

Client Responsibilities may include, but are not limited to:

•   Organizing appropriate staff to participate in kick-off call, which may include:

  • Project Leaders
  • Technology Specialists
  • Training Staff/Schoology Power Users

•   Communicating with Schoology Client Success Specialists on:

  • Branding
  • SSO (if desired)
  • Domain customization

•   Editing existing user accounts

•   Creating users

•   Creating courses

•   Enrolling users

•   Completion of product training course

•   Review of the Help Center

Client Success Specialist Responsibilities

Client Success Specialist responsibilities may include, but are not limited to:

•   Introducing the client to Schoology through a kick-off call

•   Understanding the organization’s goals for implementation

•   Helping the organization establish:

  • Branding
  • SSO
  • Domain customization
  • Support Contacts
  • System framework

•   1-1 Consulting (email or phone call)

  • Follow-up review of framework (if desired by client)
  • Follow-up after product-course completion (if desired by client)

•   Weekly check-in emails

•   Transition to on-going support at the end of implementation

 

Step 1: Setting Up The Framework 

Roles, Permissions, Privacy

Schoology is a system based on roles and permissions. Every user inside of Schoology is associated with a specific role, and the System Administrator can customize the permissions associated with each role in order to establish what each role can and cannot do.

Roles

Roles categorize the type of account for each user in the system. By default, there are four (4) basic roles for your school: Student, Instructor, Administrator, Parent. As a System Administrator, you can create new roles at any time.

Roles allow you to use the Permissions area to turn on/off any feature for a select category of users. For example, if you want to disable certain features for a small subset of users, you can create a role called “Limited Student” and adjust the permissions to limit their ability to post content on Schoology.

Navigate to the Roles area of Schoology by clicking here.  Use our Roles Guide will help you get familiar with this area.

Permissions

Navigate to the Permissions area of Schoology to research the categories of permissions available for each role.  You’ll find contact information for further assistance in our Permissions Guide.

Privacy

Navigate to the Privacy area of Schoology to place privacy thresholds at your school or organization. Our Privacy Overrides Guide can help you understand each setting.

 

Step 2: Creating and Managing Users

To create and manage user information, navigate to the Edit Users area of your Schoology admin profile. The tabs along the top allow you to access different kinds of information and perform actions associated with this information.

Below are a few key things to know:

  • Users can login using a Username, an Email Address, or either.
  • Unique IDs (used to match users with other systems like an SIS) must be unique throughout your entire Schoology system.

Our Edit Users Guide can help you to manage your users effectively.

Create Users

Choose one of four method options to create and manage your users: SSO, Google, Import or Access Codes.

Option 1: Single Sign-On (SSO)

You can set up Single Sign-On between your organization’s directory (e.g. LDAP, AD, or OD) and Schoology. This configuration will allow you to:

  • Manage user credentials from a centralized location
  • Login to Schoology from an outside area (e.g. your website portal)

To set up SSO, navigate to your Schoology Remote Authentication Settings. Our Remote Authentication Guide can help you through this process. 

Option 2: Google Provisioning:

You can provision your users over from Google Apps for Education. To provision users from Google accounts, navigate to your Schoology External Account Management Settings. Our External Account Management Guide can help you through this process.

  • You cannot provision users into a specific school.  Instead, all users will be provisioned into the district account, where you may move them into the appropriate school buildings using a CSV or XLS import file.
  • Once your Google accounts are in Schoology, their Unique ID will be the prefix of their email (e.g. jsmith@gmail.com will be jsmith).
  • Note: Since the Unique ID must be the prefix of the Google email, this may cause conflicts when exporting out of your SIS and into Schoology (e.g. course enrollment imports).

Option 3: Import

You can provision your users using a CSV or XLS import file, perhaps exported from your SIS or another database. To import users with a CSV or XLS, navigate to your Schoology Import Page. Our User Import Guide can help you through this process.

Option 4: Access Codes

Instead of importing users into your system, you can allow users to use access codes to register for their Schoology accounts.

  • To allow teachers to register by access code, navigate to your Schoology System Settings. Our System Settings Guide can help you with this process.
  • Teachers can also distribute access codes to individual students, which allows students to register their accounts. The Access Code portion of our Instructor Guide details this process.

Note: We recommend importing your users into the system so that their accounts are associated with a Unique ID. 

 

Step 3: Course Creation

Set up Grading Periods

You must set up your grading periods to establish the length of your courses. To set up your grading periods, navigate to the Grade Settings tab in your Schoology System Settings. Our Grade Settings Guide can help you through this process.

Create Courses

Choose one of two methods for course creation: ImportorManual. We recommend that you use the Import option, because this option allows you to enroll the teachers and students yourself.

Option 1: Import Courses 

This option allows you to import course information using a CSV or XLS file. To import course information, navigate to the courses tab in your Schoology Import area. Our Import Courses Guide can help you in this process.

Option 2: Manually Create Courses

Manually creating courses in your Schoology system is an easy three-step process. Your faculty can create their own courses as needed. The Course Creation portion of our Instructor Guide can help you and your faculty in this process.

 

Step 4: Course Enrollment 

Choose one of two methods: Import or Manual.

Option 1: Import

  • Use this area of Schoology to Import: http://www.schoology.com/import/course_enrollments
  • Find instructions: https://schoology.zendesk.com/entries/23214533-Import-Comprehensive-Guide-to-the-Four-Tabs 

Option 2: Manually Create Courses

  • Users can join courses by entering an access code, or teachers can use the Add Members button to manually add students.
  • Find instructions: https://schoology.zendesk.com/entries/23229467-Courses-Add-Members-to-Courses

After you complete this fourth step, the majority of your framework is complete!

 

Site Survey

We recommend performing the following tasks for optimal performance:

  • Check System Requirements.
  • Run a speed test during the school or work day.
  • Add Schoology to your whitelist.
  • Check your firewall settings for blocks against common URLs.
  • Open ports 443, 8080, and 80.
  • Send us your school or organization’s IP address to add to our whitelist.

 

After Set Up: Product Training

During implementation, your Client Success Specialist will support you in training a small group of Schoology power users and project leaders. This group will be given the opportunity to review key Schoology features in-depth, discuss best practices, and utilize support and training materials with their Client Success Specialist.

In addition to the product training services provided in the initial consultation, Schoology also offers optional train-the-trainer sessions, which may be purchased by contacting your sales representative.

 

Ongoing Support

Schoology offers two levels of support:

  1. The first level is community-based support, which is available to all administrators and instructors via a “Feedback/Support” button located in the dropdown menu in the upper right corner of Schoology. Community support is helpful for finding frequently asked questions and for posting new ideas. As part of your support management practices, you may choose to recommend this level of support for teachers and other staff or faculty at your school.
  2. The second level is dedicated support. As an enterprise client you have access to our dedicated support. You may choose up to three (3) dedicated support contacts from your school/district, whose role is to relay any questions, concerns or ideas to the Schoology team. These three (3) main support contacts can contact Schoology by:

i. Phone: Support contacts may contact a Schoology representative by using a support code listed in the Feedback/Support button (only visible to support contacts).

ii. Email: Support contacts may email a Schoology representative. 

iii. Ticketing System: Support contacts may create their own support tickets by going directly to support.schoology.com. 

 

Advanced API Provisioning 

Instead of manually setting up your system using imports, you can also use our API to programmatically add users and courses into your system from your SIS.

  • First, request your API key.
  • Then find additional documentation here: https://developers.schoology.com/api.
    • API User Creation (Advanced)
    • API Course Provisioning (Advanced)
      • Similar to user imports
      • Note: you need to create the courses before you can create the course sections

       

    • API Section Provisioning (Advanced)

    • API Course Enrollment (Advanced)
